node.title: Travis Scott says he'll cover funeral expenses for Astroworld victims
node.description: Scott, who was performing at the time of the surge, is facing multiple lawsuits.

node.title: What's behind the push for a fourth stimulus check
node.description: IRS has distributed almost 170 million payments. But hardship remains widespread as the Delta variant spreads.

node.title: Family says ex-U.S. Marine on hunger strike in Russian prison
node.description: Lawyers and family say Trevor Reed is refusing food to protest solitary confinement, "and other serious violations of his rights in the penal colony."

node.title: How climate change threatens pregnant women
node.description: World leaders turn their attention Tuesday to climate change and gender during the global U.N. summit.

node.title: "Time is short" as U.S. races to avert all-out civil war in Ethiopia
node.description: U.S. joins African Union in a last-ditch bid to stop Ethiopia's already catastrophic year-old conflict from spiraling into a much broader war.

node.title: "Tank taxi" offers fun and unique rides — though not the smoothest
node.description: In Norwich, England, Merlin Batchelor got so many requests for rides he made it into a business. The lifts go for about $1,000 each.

node.title: Oscar Pistorius up for parole, but he must meet with victim's parents
node.description: The famous double-amputee athlete was convicted of murder for fatally shooting model Reva Steenkamp in 2013.

node.title: Parole again recommended for Manson follower Leslie Van Houten
node.description: She and other followers fatally stabbed a husband and wife and smeared their blood on the walls.

node.title: 57 million pounds of pandemic-related plastics polluting the ocean
node.description: Researchers said plastic waste generated from hospitals, PPE and packaging material only added to an "already out-of-control problem."

node.title: Tension mounts as soldiers and migrants mass at Belarus-Poland border
node.description: Belarus's Russian-backed leader insists he's "not seeking a fight," but Polish and European leaders accuse him of mounting a "hybrid attack," using innocent migrants as a weapon.

node.title: Accused Capitol rioter seeks political asylum in Belarus
node.description: Evan Neumann was placed on the FBI's Most Wanted List in March.

node.title: Manchester United star receives MBE for his fight against child hunger
node.description: The English soccer star dedicated the award to his mother, who raised him and his siblings as a single mother.

node.title: Climate change conspiracies spreading rapidly during COP26
node.description: Amplified by bots and influencers, millions of posts on social media networks peddle false ideas about climate change.

node.title: Want a Zillow home? Not so fast, flippers.
node.description: Gluts of cheap homes unlikely, considering buying interest from corporate rental giants and longer renovation times.

node.title: Pediatric nurse hasn't considered retirement after 50 years
node.description: The Virginia nurse estimated she has helped care for nearly 50,000 babies — and she doesn't plan to stop.

node.title: Cardona says "no need" for hybrid or remote learning after kids are vaccinated
node.description: Cardona said it "wasn't a mistake" to keep schools closed throughout the COVID-19 pandemic.

node.title: GOP congressman gets threats after backing infrastructure bill
node.description: Congressman Fred Upton was among the 13 Republican lawmakers supported the bipartisan infrastructure bill.

node.title: Malala Yousafzai gets married: "A precious day in my life"
node.description: The Pakistani activist said she married partner Asser at a ceremony in Birmingham, England.

node.title: NASA says first Artemis moon landing now expected in 2025
node.description: NASA touts reorganization, resumption of moon lander work as keys to 2025 moon landing.

node.title: Travis Scott and organizers should have stopped Astroworld, fire chief says
node.description: "We all have a responsibility when we attend these venues to ensure each other's safety," the fire chief said.

node.title: Boy "fighting for his life" after he was trampled at Astroworld, lawyers say
node.description: The boy has been placed in a medically induced coma to combat brain, liver and kidney trauma, lawyers said.

node.title: House January 6 committee subpoenas close Trump allies
node.description: The subpoenas show that the committee is delving deeper into the actions of Mr. Trump himself leading up to and on January 6.

node.title: Sununu rejects "debate and talk" of Senate, will run again for governor
node.description: "I'd rather push myself 120 miles an hour delivering wins for New Hampshire than to slow down, end up on Capitol Hill, debating partisan politics without results," Sununu said.

node.title: Drone video shows Rittenhouse fatally shooting man at close range
node.description: Jurors viewed the clearest video yet of the fatal shooting of Joseph Rosenbaum.

node.title: Trump-endorsed Senate candidate denies estranged wife's allegations
node.description: Sean Parnell said he never choked his estranged wife or pinned her down, as she had accused him of doing,

node.title: Justices weigh case of Texas inmate who wants pastor to pray at execution
node.description: Attorneys for John Henry Ramirez argued he is not challenging his conviction, death sentence or method of execution.

node.title: Pfizer asks FDA to authorize booster shot for all adults
node.description: The Pfizer booster is currently recommended for seniors and other higher-risk adults.

node.title: OSHA's vax rule is on hold. Employers urged to still comply.
node.description: Businesses risk being caught unprepared if the regulation survives legal challenges, employment lawyers warn.

node.title: Crowd cheers female hockey goalie targeted by vulgar, sexist chants
node.description: Fans turned out to support a female goalie after students from a rival high school chanted vulgar and sexist slurs at her during a game last week.

node.title: "Squid Game 2" is currently in the works, creator says
node.description: "There will indeed be a second season," Hwang Dong-hyuk told reporters Monday.

node.title: How the infrastructure bill could expand broadband access
node.description: The bill awaiting President Joe Biden's signature includes $65 billion to help close the digital divide.

node.title: Whistleblowers to play key role in enforcing vaccine rule
node.description: OSHA is counting on employees to notify the safety agency if businesses violate the new federal COVID-19 order.

node.title: Aaron Rodgers says he takes "full responsibility" for vaccine comments
node.description: The Green Bay Packers quarterback revealed last week that he has not been vaccinated and has faced heavy criticism for saying in August that he was "immunized."

node.title: Planning your Thanksgiving meal? Better shop early
node.description: Turkey farms report selling out of birds earlier than usual amid increased demand for the key holiday menu item.

node.title: Body of missing University of Alabama student found in river, police say
node.description: Garrett Walker had disappeared early Sunday morning.

node.title: Anonymous app offers support to veterans suffering with mental health
node.description: Some veterans feel there's a stigma around seeking help for mental health. The app seeks to break down those barriers.

node.title: Brian Williams leaving NBC News at the end of the year
node.description: Williams said in a note to colleagues that "following much reflection," he had decided to exit when his contract ends in December.

node.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
node.description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.

node.title: New Zealand’s Sea Lions Are Back, and Crashing Golf Courses and Soccer Matches
node.description: After their populations were decimated by hunters, New Zealand’s sea lions are returning to the coasts — sometimes surprising locals by turning up in unexpected places.

node.title: In Oaxaca, a Meal to Celebrate a Pioneering Artist’s Legacy
node.description: To fete the opening of a new exhibition of work by — and inspired by — Ana Mendieta, the curator Su Wu gathered friends for a comal-cooked brunch prepared by chef Thalia Barrios Garcia.

node.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘His Skin Against Mine’
node.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

node.title: Thandiwe Newton Feeds Her Soul With Critical Race Theory and Cleo Sol
node.description: The “Westworld” actress talks about her new Audible recording of Tolstoy’s “War and Peace” and why too much entertainment can be bad for you.

node.title: The Fresh Prince of Belles-Lettres? Will Smith Has a Memoir.
node.description: From rap stardom to movie stardom, “Will” traces its hero’s quest out of West Philadelphia.

node.title: Álvarez, Boxing’s Undisputed King, Is a Target for Fighters and Promoters
node.description: Would-be foes and matchmakers see the 168-pound champion as a path to a career payday.

node.title: Marcel Hug and Madison de Rozario Win N.Y.C. Marathon Wheelchair Races
node.description: Hug, a four-time champion, dominated the men’s division, while de Rozario won her first women’s title, pulling away in the second half of the race.

node.title: Playing It Safe, Giants Steal a Win From the Raiders
node.description: Are the Giants watchable yet? Not if you like offense.

node.title: Saturday’s Cal-U.S.C. game has been delayed by Covid.
node.description: The matchup is the first game of the season at college football’s top level to be rescheduled because of the virus.

node.title: How hot is lava erupting from Hawaii’s Kilauea volcano?
node.description: Test your science knowledge.

node.title: Should the Democrats Be Less Progressive?
node.description: Readers respond to an editorial that urged the party to be more realistic and moderate. Also: Aaron Rodgers; the anguish of war.

node.title: How Data Is Reshaping Real Estate
node.description: Tech start-ups are offering new tools to help retailers and entertainment venues be more efficient by counting crowds, tracking foot traffic and following local shopping habits.

node.title: The Making of a Feel-Bad Boom
node.description: What do people mean when they talk about “the economy”?

node.title: Is a Red Wave Coming for Biden’s Presidency?
node.description: The Republican Party has a lot of news to celebrate after last week’s elections. Why are voters cooling toward the Democratic Party?

node.title: If It’s Not Critical Race Theory, It’s Critical Race Theory-lite
node.description: The country’s education debate isn’t made up.

node.title: The Climate Summit Has Me Very Energized, and Very Afraid
node.description: Much of the world wouldn't make sacrifices to fight Covid, so why think it will to stop climate change?

node.title: Twitter expands its subscription service to news articles.
node.description: The company is pushing to find new sources of revenue.

node.title: Why Wokeness Will Fail
node.description: Americans won’t support a protest movement that divides, undermines, and censors.

node.title: Tesla shares slide 12 percent as Musk’s stock-sale pledge continues to reverberate.
node.description: Since Friday, Tesla has shed about $200 billion in market valuation.

node.title: New Initiative Aims to Change How Movies Portray Muslims
node.description: An advocacy group has created a worker database with help from Disney to bring more Muslims into the filmmaking process.

node.title: ‘It went to my head’: Adam Neumann has regrets about his time at WeWork.
node.description: He also tried to revise the record about what happened.

node.title: Workhorse Group records a big loss on electric vans.
node.description: The company, which lost its bid for a big Postal Service contract, has told investors it is under federal investigation.

node.title: Oklahoma Supreme Court Throws Out $465 Million Opioid Ruling Against J.&J.
node.description: The 5-1 decision is a setback for those who are fighting to hold big drug makers accountable for the opioid epidemic.

node.title: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, says paid family leave ‘is not just about the mom.’
node.description: “It sets us up for economic growth and success, but it also just allows people to have that very sacred time as a family.”

node.title: Judge denies Apple’s request to delay App Store changes.
node.description: Apple may have to rewrite its policies to allow app developers to point users to alternative payment methods as soon as December.

node.title: Bittersweet Memories of Grand Prospect Hall
node.description: For couples married at the more than century-old venue in Brooklyn, which is now approved for demolition, their memories will soon be all they have left.

node.title: Gotham, in the Former Gotham Bar & Grill Space, Nods to Its Predecessor
node.description: A new steak spot from Laurent Tourondel, Le Coucou’s long-awaited reopening, and more restaurant news.

node.title: Starbucks workers at three more Buffalo-area stores file for union elections.
node.description: The petitions were submitted as employees at three other stores prepared to vote in a unionization effort.

node.title: Sununu to Run Again for New Hampshire Governor, Rejecting Senate Bid
node.description: National Republicans had seen a potential campaign by Gov. Chris Sununu against Senator Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, as one of their best shots to upend the Senate’s 50-50 split.

node.title: Where’s Gov. Gavin Newsom?
node.description: He’s in the office, according to increasingly frustrated staff members. But his critics on Twitter aren’t buying it.

node.title: Max Cleland, Vietnam Veteran and Former Senator, Dies at 79
node.description: He lost both legs and an arm in the war. Republicans impugned his patriotism by linking him to Osama bin Laden in an infamous TV spot.

node.title: Moderna and U.S. at Odds Over Vaccine Patent Rights
node.description: Moderna’s patent application names several employees as the sole inventors of a crucial component of its coronavirus vaccine, excluding three government scientists.

node.title: NASA Moves Moon Landing Deadline Back to 2025
node.description: The space agency acknowledged that it cannot return astronauts to the lunar surface by 2024, a timeline set under President Trump.

node.title: Pfizer Asks F.D.A. to Expand Booster Eligibility to All Adults
node.description: In a turnaround, the agency is expected to grant the request before the winter holiday season, giving access to all 181 million fully vaccinated people.

node.title: Trump Officials Illegally Campaigned While in Office, Watchdog Finds
node.description: Mr. Trump’s son-in-law and his chief of staff are among those accused of violating a law designed to prevent federal employees from abusing their power.

node.title: Supreme Court Looks at Puerto Rico’s Status in Case on Benefits
node.description: A federal law excludes residents of Puerto Rico from a Social Security program that provides monthly payments to needy people.

node.title: At the Willard and the White House, the Jan. 6 Panel Widens Its Net
node.description: What went on at a five-star hotel near the White House the day before the riot could be a window into how a Trump-directed plot to upend the election ended in violence at the Capitol.

node.title: Supreme Court Weighs Condemned Man’s Wish for Pastor’s Touch
node.description: A Texas death row inmate, John H. Ramirez, asked the justices to let spiritual advisers pray with and lay hands on prisoners as they await execution.

node.title: ‘We Had Their Baby, and They Had Our Baby’: Couple Sues Over Embryo ‘Mix-Up’
node.description: Daphna and Alexander Cardinale, the plaintiffs in a lawsuit against a Los Angeles-area fertility clinic, say they endured a painful custody exchange after DNA testing.

node.title: Do Democrats Have a Messaging Problem?
node.description: Some critics say the Democratic Party is struggling to respond to issues seized upon by conservative news media.

node.title: Los Angeles businesses confront a new vaccination mandate.
node.description: Thousands of gyms, restaurants, movie theaters, shopping malls, salons and other businesses are now required to ask customers for proof of vaccination.

node.title: Travis Scott’s Ties to Houston Could Complicate Investigation of Fatal Concert
node.description: There are worries about conflicts of interest in the criminal investigation into the deaths of eight concertgoers during Mr. Scott’s performance at the Astroworld festival.

node.title: Frontline health workers in England will be required to be vaccinated by April.
node.description: About 80,000 to 100,000 National Health Service workers in the country remain unvaccinated against the coronavirus.

node.title: Canada approves Pfizer-BioNTech boosters for all adults.
node.description: Some provinces have already started to offer booster shots to higher-risk populations. Tuesday’s announcement standardizes eligibility criteria nationwide.

node.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
node.description: India’s Covid turnaround has blind spots.

node.title: Pakistan Reaches Cease-Fire With Resurgent Taliban Militants
node.description: The Pakistani government said it would offer amnesty for insurgents who are willing to disarm.

node.title: Malala Yousafzai Is Married in England
node.description: Ms. Yousafzai, a Pakistani activist and the youngest-ever recipient of a Nobel Peace Prize, married her partner at a small ceremony in Birmingham, England, she said on Twitter.

node.title: Pennsylvania School Districts Take GOP Leaders to Court Over Increasing Education Funding
node.description: The lawsuit states that 38 percent of the state's budget goes toward education, lower than the national average.

node.title: Racial Slurs Written in Frost on Cars in College's Student Lot Prompt Investigation
node.description: "We unequivocally condemn this kind of behavior. We pray for and stand ready to support those who were affected," the Providence College president said.

node.title: Oklahoma Court Overturns $465M J&J Opioid Settlement, Says Drugmaker Didn't Violate Law
node.description: "The court has allowed public nuisance claims to address discrete, localized problems, not policy problems," said the written opinion.

node.title: With Holidays Approaching, Pfizer Asks FDA to Approve COVID Boosters for All Adults
node.description: Pfizer asks the FDA to give the OK for all adults to get vaccine booster shots before holiday travelings and gatherings are upon us.

node.title: COVID Nurse Has Hands, Feet Amputated After Catching Meningitis on Vacation
node.description: Jon Aquino, a father of two from New Jersey, also developed sepsis and suffered from liver and kidney failure.

node.title: 30,000 Cases Detected of AY.4.2. COVID Variant That Could Spread Faster Than Original Delta
node.description: Scientists are investigating the off-shoot of Delta, which has been detected in 11 U.S. states, to see what advantages it may have over past forms of COVID.

node.title: Yellowstone Volcano's Last Supereruption Started with Decades of Explosions
node.description: Scientists studying the Lava Creek Tuff eruption have found unusual rocks linked to the event 631,000 years ago.

node.title: Amazing Photos Show Moon, Saturn, Venus, Jupiter Lining Up in the Sky
node.description: Stargazers are also being treated to the sight of the moon approaching and then bypassing each of the three planets this week.

node.title: COVID 40 Times More Likely to Kill Unvaccinated Texans, Study Suggests, As 54% Have Both Shots
node.description: The figure was reported in a new study published by the Texas Department of State Health Services as the state is behind most others in terms of full vaccinations.

node.title: Facebook Whistleblower Faults Zuckerberg for 'Failure of Leadership,' Profits Over Safety
node.description: "They keep making unforced errors," Frances Haugen told the Associated Press. "They keep making things that prioritize their own profits over our safety."

node.title: Eiffel Tower-Sized Asteroid to Pass Earth Days Before Geminid Meteor Shower
node.description: The space rock will be traveling at more than 14,000 miles per hour when it flies by our planet in December.

node.title: Kayaker Catches Flesh-Eating Bacteria After Falling Into Florida Channel
node.description: Former Atlanta Hawks president Bob Williams said he had to undergo surgery on his feet in order to remove the deadly infection.

node.title: Honey Bees Scream as They Are Attacked by Giant Hornets
node.description: These shrieks precede group defensive behavior, where the bees smear poop around their nests to repel hornets.

node.title: NJ Kids Can Mow Lawns, Open Lemonade Stands Without Permits as Statewide Crackdown Ends
node.description: A state lawmaker who sponsored the new law called the requirements for children in other states "absolute nonsense" and a "smack down on entrepreneurial kids."

node.title: Once Dominant General Electric to Split Into Three Public Companies: 'It's Over Now'
node.description: Breaking up the conglomerate could urge other multi-industry companies to "demerge" in the future, say industry experts.
